Fig. 1 X-ray diffraction patterns of the Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at the indicated temperatures without A) or with B) subsequent reduction. Ru content: 3 wt%. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Transmission electron microscope images and size distributions of Ru particles for reduced Ru/MgO. Ru content: 3 wt%, A: Ru/MgO calcined at 773 K, B: Ru/MgO calcined at 923 K. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 H2 temperature-programmed reduction profiles of the Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at various temperatures. Ru content: 3 wt%, A) 773 K, B) 823 K, C) 873 K, and D) 923 K. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 X-ray photoelectron spectra of the reduced Ru/MgO catalysts calcined at (A) 773 K and (B) 923 K. Ru content: 3 wt%. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra obtained by CO adsorption on the reduced Ru/MgO catalysts calcined at different temperatures. Ru content: 3 wt%, A) 773 K, B) 823 K, C) 873 K, and D) 923 K. The dotted lines indicate fitted component peaks. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Hydrogen production rates of Ru/MgO catalyst doped with various metal ions and calcined at 923 K. Ru content: 3 wt%, additive content: 2 wt%, reaction temperature: 673 K, Conversion of NH3 was adjusted to be about 5% by regulating the supply rate of the NH3 gas. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effect of Cs doping on H2 production rate of Cs–Ru/MgO catalysts calcined at 773 K ( Image 1 ) and 923 K ( Image 2 ). Ru content: 3 wt%. Cs content measured by ICP was shown in Table S1. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Transmission electron microscope images and size distributions of the Ru particles of the reduced Cs-Ru/MgO catalysts. Critical role of Cs doping in the structure and NH3 decomposition performance of Ru/MgO catalysts Isao Nakamura Data curation, Writing − original draft a Hidehito Kubo Visualization, Project administration b Tadahiro Fujitani Conceptualization, Data curation, Writing − original draft, Visualization, Project administration a ⁎ a Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8565, Japan Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) Tsukuba Ibaraki 305-8565 Japan Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305–8565, Japan b Engineering Department No.1, Toyota Industries Corporation, Obu-shi, Aichi 474-8601, Japan Engineering Department No.1, Toyota Industries Corporation Obu-shi Aichi 474-8601 Japan Engineering Department No.1, Toyota Industries Corporation, Obu-shi, Aichi, 474–8601, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. The NH3 decomposition activity of Ru/MgO catalysts for the production of H2 decreases with increasing calcination temperature. Here, we found that this decrease in activity was the result of the interaction between the Ru and MgO support becoming stronger, causing formation of cationic Ru species. To mitigate this decrease in activity, we investigated the use of doping Ru/MgO catalysts with rare earth, alkali, or alkaline earth metals and found that Cs was particularly effective at enhancing catalytic activity, even at high calcination temperatures. Further examination revealed that doping with Cs weakened the interaction between the Ru and MgO support, resulting in the production of metallic Ru species. The metallic Ru produced by the doping of Cs enhanced the associative desorption of N atoms, which is the rate-limiting step of the NH3 decomposition reaction. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NH3 decomposition Ru/MgO Cs promoter Reduction of Ru oxides Electronic state of Ru Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2) is a promising alternative energy resource and potential means of addressing social concerns about the exhaustion of fossil fuels and increases in environmental degradation. H2 is being considered because it is a clean fuel with a high energy capacity, and it is available for various applications such as high-efficiency power generation systems, distributed energy generation systems, and fuel cells for automobiles. The major obstacles for its practical application are the transportation and storage of H2. It is possible to transport and store H2 in liquid form, but the liquefaction and vaporization of H2 consume large amounts of energy, increasing the cost of this approach [1]. Thus, various H2 carriers, that is, chemicals that can be easily transported and stored and then converted to pure H2 when needed, such as methanol, hydrazine, ammonia (NH3), hydrides, and formic acid, have been proposed [2–4]. Among these materials, NH3 is considered a promising candidate H2 carrier because of the high storage capacity of hydrogen (about 18 wt%), high energy density (3000 Wh/kg), and easy liquefaction [2]. Furthermore, from an economic standpoint, NH3 decomposition is a better process for H2 generation compared to methanol reforming [5]. Thus, NH3 would play an important role in the future realization of hydrogen economy. NH3 is a very stable molecule that does not easily undergo thermal decomposition because of its extremely high activation energy. Therefore, when NH3 is utilized as hydrogen carrier, an active catalyst for NH3 decomposition is necessary. To date, various catalysts have been reported, and the Ru nanoparticle catalysts has been demonstrated to be the most effective for the direct decomposition of NH3 [6–9]. However, it has also been found that the method used to prepare Ru-based catalysts greatly affects their NH3 decomposition activity. The effects of Ru precursors [10–12], methods for supporting the Ru [11,13–18], and type of support [19–23] on NH3 decomposition activity have been investigated using Ru powder catalysts supported on various metal oxides and carbon materials. Ju et al. [13] have examined the catalytic activity for NH3 decomposition of Ru/MgO catalysts produced by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) and deposition–precipitation (DP) methods and have reported that the catalyst produced by DP was highly active compared with that produced by IWI. Our group has also performed the synthesis of Ru/MgO catalysts by various preparation methods, and we have found that Ru/MgO catalysts produced by DP and coprecipitation (CP) methods show a higher activity for NH3 decomposition reaction than those prepared by IWI [14]. We conclude that the improved catalytic performance of the DP and CP catalysts is due to the formation of MgO mesopores and high dispersion of supported Ru particles. To improve the NH3 decomposition activity of supported Ru catalysts, the effects of doping with alkali metals such as Li [24,25], Na [26–28], K [10,23,29–34], and Cs [11,15,16,35,36] have been widely studied. Yin et al. [10,30,31] have reported that modification of carbon nanotubes or ZrO2 with potassium hydroxide results in a marked increase in the NH3 decomposition activity of Ru catalysts using those materials as supports. Based on these findings, they speculate that it can produce a high-performance Ru catalyst by using supports made of electron-conductive materials with strong basicity. Hill and Torrente-Murciano [35,36] have examined the influence of Cs doping on NH3 decomposition over a Ru/carbon nanotube catalyst and have found that it enhances catalytic activity, which they attribute to electronic modification of Ru by electron-donating Cs. Nagaoka et al. [37] prepared Ru/Pr6O11 catalysts doped with various types of basic oxides and found that Ru/Pr6O11 doped with Cs2O, which has the strongest basicity, exhibited the highest NH3 conversion rate among the examined catalysts. This high conversion rate was ascribed to improved electron donation to Ru afforded by the addition of Cs. Previously, we found that Ru/MgO catalysts produced by CP have high activity at low reaction temperatures for the production of H2 via the decomposition of NH3 [14]. However, we also found that while these catalysts have high initial activity, their activity gradually decreases with reaction time [38]. This decrease in activity is caused by a change of the structure of the catalyst during the reaction, possibly due to a low thermal stability of the catalyst. In the present study, we demonstrated that the NH3 decomposition activity on Ru/MgO significantly decreased with increasing calcination temperature. For Ni-based catalyst, on the other hand, Feng et al. [39,40] have reported the effect of the calcination temperature of the catalyst on the NH3 decomposition activity and the long-term stability of the catalytic activity. They concluded that the Ni/La2O3 catalyst showed higher NH3 decomposition activity at lower calcination temperature, which was due to the high surface area, basicity strength and concentration of surface oxygen species of the catalyst [39]. For Ru catalyst, we investigated the cause for the observed decrease in activity of Ru/MgO calcined at high temperature and made improvements to suppress this decrease of activity. We found that doping with Cs was effective not only for mitigating the decrease of activity induced by high-temperature calcination, but also for improving the initial catalytic activity of Ru/MgO catalyst. Thus, we report details on the critical role of Cs doping in the structure and NH3 decomposition performance of Ru/MgO catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The Ru/MgO catalysts were produced by means of a CP method. Details of the catalyst preparation method were described elsewhere [14]. Briefly, an aqueous mixture of RuCl3 and Mg(NO3)2 and an aqueous solution of K2CO3 were added dropwise simultaneously to distilled water with stirring at 5000 rpm using homogenizer. Subsequently, the mixture was statically placed for 24 h at 298 K; the precipitates were separated by filtration, washed with ion exchange water, then dried at 383 K and calcined in air at 773–923 K. The loading amount of Ru was 3 wt%. Catalysts promoted by rare earth, alkali, or alkaline earth metals were produced by impregnating the Ru/MgO catalyst with an aqueous solution of the appropriate metal nitrate and then calcining them to 773–923 K for 2 h. 2.2 Characterization The specific surface area and the crystal structure of the catalyst were determined by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The Ru surface area and the Ru particle size were estimated from pulse CO chemisorption and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements. Detailed methods of these experiments were described elsewhere [14]. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed as follows. The catalyst was heated at 723 K for 30 min in Ar before each measurement. After cooling to 323 K, the Ar gas was switched to 10% H2/Ar gas. Then, H2-TPR profiles were obtained with a heating rate of 10 K/min. The measurements of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were performed on an ESCALAB 250 (VG Scientific) spectrometer by Al-kα radiation. The XP spectra were measured with a pass energy of 20 eV and a step size of 0.1 eV, which gives an Ag 3d5/2 peak at 368.2 eV for pure silver that has a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 0.61 eV. The spectra were referenced to the Fermi level, which shows the Ru 3d5/2 peak at 280.0 eV for a clean Ru(0001) single crystal. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) measurements for CO adsorption were performed on a FTIR/6300 spectrometer (JASCO) equipped with a reaction cell (DR-650FV-C, JASCO), calcium fluoride windows, and a mercury–cadmium–telluride detector. Before measurement, each fresh catalyst was treated in 10% H2/Ar gas at 773 K for 1 h. Then, the gas flow was switched to pure Ar, and the samples were cooled to 323 K. After the temperature of the sample had stabilized, the reaction cell was evacuated at 10−3 Pa for 30 min by using a differential pumping system (Hi CUBE, PFEFFER), and the background spectrum of the sample was recorded. Then, a 10% CO/Ar gas mixture was slowly introduced to the reactor cell, and the catalyst surface was exposed to CO for 10 min. The reaction cell was evacuated again, and the spectra were recorded in the resolution of 4 cm−1. The Cs content in the Cs–Ru/MgO catalysts was measured by means of inductively coupled plasma (ICP) atomic emission spectrometer (ICPE-9820, Shimadzu). Before measurements, every catalyst was digested in acidic solutions, which was sprayed into ICP and spectral intensities were obtained. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of N atoms produced by NH3 decomposition was performed by using a mass spectrometer (LCD200M, Tilon GRP Technology Ltd.). Before the measurement, the samples were activated at 773 K in a 10% H2/Ar gas mixture for 1 h. The reduced catalysts were exposed to 10% NH3/Ar mixture for 30 min at 773 K, and the samples were cooled to 373 K. Then, the gas flow was switched to Ar. After a stable baseline was obtained in a flow of Ar at 373 K, the sample was heated at 10 K/min to record the TPD curve. 2.3 Catalytic activity The procedure of NH3 decomposition reaction and the analysis of product were same as those shown in elsewhere [14]. Turnover frequency (TOF) of the sample was calculated from the rate of H2 production and Ru surface area, assuming the Ru(0001) plane of the close-packed surface was exposed (1.58 × 1019 atoms/m2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of calcination temperature on the Ru/MgO catalyst First, we investigated the effect of calcination temperature (773–923 K) on the physicochemical and reaction properties of the Ru/MgO catalyst ( Table 1). Specific surface area decreased, and mean pore diameter increased with increasing calcination temperature, indicating that sintering of the MgO support was significantly promoted with increasing calcination temperature. The surface area of the Ru metal in the Ru/MgO catalyst obtained from pulse CO chemisorption also gradually decreased with increasing calcination temperature. The rate of H2 production by NH3 decomposition decreased with increasing calcination temperature. In particular, the catalytic activity was markedly decreased at temperatures above 873 K; the H2 production rate at 923 K decreased by 40% compared with that at 773 K. Furthermore, the TOF gradually decreased with increasing calcination temperature. Because NH3 decomposition over Ru-based catalysts takes place on the Ru metal itself [41,42], the decrease in TOF indicates a change in the chemical state of the Ru surface. To examine this further, the activation energy of the Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at each temperature was estimated by means of an Arrhenius plot (Fig. S1, in Supporting information). The increase of the activation energy slightly with increasing calcination temperature further confirms that the active sites of the catalyst are qualitatively changed with increasing calcination temperature. 3.2 Characterization of the Ru/MgO catalyst To clarify the cause of the decrease in catalytic activity by calcination at high temperature, we carried out various characterizations of the Ru/MgO catalyst. Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns of the Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at various temperatures (773–923 K) without or with subsequent reduction at 773 K. After calcination alone (Fig. 1A), only diffraction peaks attributable to MgO species were observed, and no diffraction peaks due to Ru oxides or Ru metal were observed, which was probably caused by the high Ru dispersion. The intensity of the observed peaks increased with increasing calcination temperature, whereas the FWHM of the peaks decreased, indicating that crystallization of MgO was promoted with increasing calcination temperature, which was consistent with our finding that the surface area of MgO decreased with increasing calcination temperature (Table 1). After calcination and reduction (Fig. 1B), further decreases in the FWHM of the peaks were observed throughout the temperature range examined, indicating that crystallization of MgO was promoted by the reduction process. However, the degree of crystallization after reduction was less sensitive to calcination temperature than that after calcination. Next, TEM measurements were carried out to investigate the state of Ru particles supported on MgO at different calcination temperatures. Fig. 2 shows TEM images and particle size distributions for Ru/MgO calcined at different temperatures and then reduced at 773 K. In Ru/MgO calcined at 773 K, uniformly sized Ru particles of about 1.3 nm were highly dispersed on the MgO support. On the other hand, in Ru/MgO calcined at 923 K, the particle size had increased slightly to around 1.5 nm while maintaining a high dispersion state. There was no significant change in the size distribution of the Ru particles between the calcination temperatures of 773 and 923 K, indicating that the particle size of Ru was scarcely influenced by calcination temperature. However, the surface area of Ru metal decreased with increasing calcination temperature. (Table 1). It has been shown that Ru/MgO consists of Ru metal particles and RuO2 even after reduction [43]. Because RuO2 exists as small clusters stabilized via epitaxy interaction with the MgO surface [44], we believe that the interaction between Ru species and MgO is increased by calcination at high temperature, resulting in an increase in Ru oxide clusters. Therefore, the decrease in the surface area of Ru metal with increasing calcination temperature was considered to be due to the change in the reducibility of RuO2, not to sintering of the Ru particles. Next, H2-TPR was used to examine the effect of calcination temperature on the reduction properties of Ru/MgO catalysts ( Fig. 3). For comparison, the reduction properties of RuO2 and MgO were also investigated (Fig. S2, in Supporting information). MgO was found not to consume hydrogen at all, whereas a sharp reduction peak with a maximum at 430 K was observed for RuO2. For Ru/MgO calcined at 773 K, a broad reduction peak at 570 K and a sharp reduction peak at 650 K were observed, which were attributed to the reduction of Ru oxides because the MgO support was not reducible within that temperature range. Thus, the reduction of Ru oxides was shifted to a much higher temperature by supporting them on MgO, and the reduction proceeded in two steps. For the lower reduction peak, with increasing calcination temperature, the reduction temperatures of the Ru oxides shifted toward a higher value. The reduction temperature for Ru/MgO calcined at 923 K was 630 K, which was much higher than that (570 K) of Ru/MgO calcined at 773 K. This result suggests that the interaction between Ru oxides and MgO increases with increasing calcination temperature. In contrast, the reduction peak appearing at a higher temperature of 650 K did not change significantly with respect to peak temperature with increasing calcination temperature. It has been reported not only that the reduction behavior of Ru/MgO catalysts strongly depends on the preparation method, but also that the reduction of the Ru species on MgO proceeds in one step [13]. However, the present findings show that the Ru/MgO catalyst prepared by the CP method has two types of Ru oxides species, indicating that the chemical state of the Ru metal formed by the reduction of these Ru oxides can differ. Furthermore, total reduction peak area decreased with increasing calcination temperature, indicating that the interaction between Ru oxides and MgO becomes stronger with calcination temperature, resulting in a change to partially non-reducible Ru oxide species. The electronic state of Ru in Ru/MgO after reduction was investigated by XPS. Fig. 4 shows XP spectra obtained for the Ru/MgO catalysts calcined at 773 or 923 K and then reduced at 773 K. In the spectrum for Ru/MgO calcined at 773 K, the peaks were detected at 280.3 and 284.3 eV, which were assigned to Ru 3d5/2 and Ru 3d3/2 + C 1 s, respectively. The binding energy of the Ru 3d5/2 peak (280.3 eV) was slightly higher than that of the Ru metal (280.0 eV) [45], indicating that the electronic state of the supported Ru species was cationic. Also, the C 1 s peak due to a carbonate species was observed around 289 eV, suggesting that the hydromagnesite of MgO precursor partially remained on the catalyst [14]. The fact that the intensity of this peak decreased with calcination at 923 K indicates that more of the hydromagnesite decomposes to MgO with increasing calcination temperature. The Ru 3d5/2 peak was seen at 280.5 eV for the catalyst calcined at 923 K, indicating that Ru was in a more cationic state as a function of the calcination temperature. In addition, a shoulder peak was seen at 282.6 eV. Because the Ru 3d5/2 peak is observed at 282.1, 282.3, and 283.1 eV for RuO2, RuO3, and RuO4, respectively [45], the Ru species observed at 280.5 eV was not an oxide; instead, it was Ru in a cationic state due to interaction with the MgO support. The peak at 282.6 eV was due to Ru oxides such as RuO3, which agreed with the result of TPR measurements (Fig. 3); that is, the formation of non-reducible Ru oxide species may be attributed to RuO3. From these results, we considered that the interaction between Ru and MgO became strong with increasing calcination temperature. The chemical states of the reduced Ru particles were also evaluated by examining CO chemisorption. Fig. 5 shows DRIFTS spectra obtained for Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at various temperatures (773–923 K) and then reduced at 773 K. A peak at around 2000 cm−1 and a shoulder peak from 1900 to 1950 cm−1 were observed at all calcination temperatures; however, the intensity of the shoulder peak increased with increasing calcination temperature. Next, the shoulder peak in the spectra was subjected to peak deconvolution (Fig. 5, dotted lines), and two peaks with maxima at around 1950 and 1900 cm−1 were observed. CO adsorption peaks at 2020–2040 cm−1 and 1950 cm−1 have been reported for Ru/MgO catalyst prepared by an impregnation method [46,47]. Furthermore, it has been reported that the frequency of CO adsorbed linearly on a Ru(0001) single crystal is shifted from 1991 to 2060 cm−1, depending on the amount of CO adsorbed [48,49]. Thus, we attributed the CO adsorption peak around 2000 cm−1 observed in the present study to be due to linear adsorption of CO on the Ru metal. In contrast, because the peak at around 1950 cm−1 appeared in Ru/MgO but does not appear in Ru(0001) single crystal, we attributed that peak to bridge-adsorbed CO because this species is more strongly adsorbed on the Ru surface than linearly adsorbed CO [50]. Furthermore, for SiO2/Ru(0001), in addition to the peak for linearly adsorbed CO, an adsorption peak at around 1940 cm−1 is reported to be attributable to CO adsorbed on the bridge site of the Ru(0001) surface [51]. Thus, the CO adsorption peak appearing at 1950 cm−1 in the present study was attributed to the creation of new CO adsorption sites, such as bridge sites, on the Ru surface by interaction with the MgO support. It has been reported that after exposure to CO at room temperature and heating to 473 K, a CO adsorption peak is observed at around 1900 cm−1, which is attributed to the CO occupying the more energetic Ru sites as a bridged species [50]. It is known that the adsorption of CO is stabilized by adsorption at defect sites such as step sites rather than at terrace sites [52]. However, it has been reported that CO adsorption at step sites of Ru appears at 1996 cm−1 [53]. Thus, the adsorption peak at around 1900 cm−1 may be related to Ru that is interacting more strongly with MgO than with the Ru site of CO adsorption observed at 1950 cm−1, indicating the possibility of two types of Ru species with different strengths of interaction with MgO. The intensity of the CO adsorption peak at 2000 cm−1 decreased, whereas that at 1900 cm−1 increased, with increasing calcination temperature. The peak intensity ratio between 2000 cm−1 and 1900 cm−1 (1900 cm−1/2000 cm−1) was estimated to be 0.42 and 0.63 at 773 K and 923 K, respectively. Thus, the number of CO linear adsorption sites on the Ru metal decreased, whereas the number of sites where CO was strongly adsorbed on the Ru surface increased, with increasing calcination temperature. For the peak at 1950 cm−1, on the other hand, the intensity was hardly affected by the calcination temperature. These results suggest that the Ru species that did not interact with MgO were changed to strongly interacting Ru species with increasing calcination temperature, which is consistent with the XPS results revealing that the electronic state of Ru became more cationic with increasing calcination temperature (Fig. 4). Thus, we considered that the cationic Ru species formed by strong interaction with the MgO support decreased catalytic performance such as TOF and activation energy. 3.3 Mitigation of the decrease of activity induced by high-temperature calcination of Ru/MgO catalysts Doping with rare earth, alkali, and alkaline earth metal ions enhances the catalytic performance of Ru/MgO catalysts [11,15,16,24–36]. We therefore investigated whether these metal ions could also mitigate the decrease of activity induced by high-temperature calcination of our Ru/MgO catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the H2 production rates of the Ru/MgO catalysts doped with various metal ions and calcined at 923 K. All of the additives examined improved the H2 production rate compared with that of the parent Ru/MgO catalyst. Addition of Cs or Ce resulted in the biggest increases in catalytic activity. The addition of Cs enhanced the activity by 3.7 times compared with that of the parent Ru/MgO catalyst. We next investigated the influence of the amount of Cs doping on the NH3 decomposition activity of our catalyst. Fig. 7 shows the effect of doping with different amounts of Cs on the H2 production rate of catalysts calcined at 773 or 923 K. The Cs content in the Cs–Ru/MgO catalysts measured by ICP was shown in Table S1 in Supporting information. At both calcination temperatures, the H2 production rate increased significantly with increasing Cs content; maximum catalytic activity was observed at 2 wt% Cs, after which, the activity lowered as the Cs content increases. No differences in the catalytic activity of the Cs-doped catalyst were observed between the catalysts calcined at the different temperatures, indicating that the addition of Cs affected the interaction between the Ru species and MgO. Table 2 summarizes the effects of calcination temperature on the physicochemical and NH3 decomposition properties of 2 wt% Cs–Ru/MgO catalyst. Throughout the calcination temperature range examined, the specific surface area of Cs–Ru/MgO was about half that of the parent Ru/MgO catalyst. Furthermore, the specific surface area markedly decreased as the calcination temperature rises, suggesting that Cs acts to promote sintering of MgO. In contrast, the Ru surface area remained high despite the decrease in the specific surface area of the catalyst. The Ru surface area and the H2 production rate remained almost constant, regardless of calcination temperature, and TOF calculated from those values also remained constant at twice that for the parent Ru/MgO catalyst. Furthermore, the activation energy for the Cs–Ru/MgO catalyst, as estimated by means of Arrhenius plot (Fig. S3, in Supporting information), was comparable at each calcination temperature, indicating that the qualitative changes in the catalytic active site with calcination temperature were largely suppressed by the addition of Cs. Thus, the Cs–Ru/MgO catalyst showed high catalytic activity even at a high calcination temperature, and the TOF was much higher than that for the parent Ru/MgO catalyst, suggesting that the state of the Ru metal supported on the MgO was modified by the addition of Cs. 3.4 Characterizations of Cs–Ru/MgO catalysts To clarify how Cs mitigated the decrease of activity induced by high-temperature calcination of our catalyst, we evaluated the characteristics of Cs–Ru/MgO using the same analytical techniques used to examine the Ru/MgO catalyst. First, the structure of Cs–Ru/MgO was examined by XRD. The XRD patterns of the Cs–Ru/MgO calcined at 773 K, regardless of Cs content, only showed peaks that were attributable to MgO species (Fig. S4A, in Supporting information), which was consistent with our earlier findings for the parent Ru/MgO catalyst (Fig. 1). However, marked increases in peak intensity and decreases in the FWHM of the peaks were observed after reduction (Fig. S4B), indicating that the crystal growth of MgO was greatly promoted by the addition of only a small amount of Cs. Furthermore, the XRD patterns of Cs–Ru/MgO calcined at 923 K showed marked crystal growth of MgO (Fig. S5A), indicating that the Cs-mediated promotion of MgO crystal growth was greater when the catalyst was calcined at high temperature. These results agreed well with our earlier finding that the specific surface area of the Cs-doped catalyst decreased significantly with calcination temperature (Table 2). However, the XRD patterns after calcination and reduction were comparable with those after calcination alone (Fig. S5B), indicating that the reduction resulted in no structural change of the MgO support. From these results, we concluded that the doping of the Ru/MgO catalyst with Cs greatly promoted MgO crystal growth and that Cs directly affected MgO, not Ru. Next, the effect of Cs on Ru particles was examined by using TEM. Fig. 8 shows TEM images and particle size distributions for Cs–Ru/MgO calcined at different temperatures and then reduced at 773 K. The average particle diameter determined from TEM images was 2.6 and 2.3 nm with calcination at 773 and 923 K, respectively. No change in Ru particle size was observed by changing the calcination temperature, but the particle sizes were larger than those for the Ru/MgO catalyst (1.3–1.5 nm, as shown in Fig. 2). Despite the larger Ru particle size in Cs–Ru/MgO, the Ru metal surface area was increased compared with that in Ru/MgO (Table 2), indicating that the formation of non-reducible Ru oxides was suppressed by the addition of Cs. The effect of Cs on the reduction properties of the Ru oxides supported on MgO was examined using H2-TPR. Fig. 9 shows H2-TPR profiles of Cs–Ru/MgO catalysts calcined at various temperatures (773–923 K). The reduction profile of Cs–Ru/MgO differed markedly from that of Ru/MgO. For the Cs–Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at 773 K, a small reduction peak appeared at around 510 K, and a sharp reduction peak appeared at 580 K, which we attributed to the peaks observed at 570 and 650 K, respectively, in the profiles for Ru/MgO (Fig. 3). A broad peak was observed around 730 K. The assignment of this broad peak is unknown at present, but we considered that it was not due to the reduction of Ru oxides because the peak area between 450 and 600 K corresponds to the amount of hydrogen used for the reduction of the supported Ru oxides. Although the reduction peaks at 510 and 580 K shifted to a higher temperature with increasing calcination temperature, the reduction peaks at 540 and 630 K seen for Cs–Ru/MgO calcined at 923 K were shifted to low temperature compared with those for Ru/MgO (Fig. 3). Thus, the reduction of Ru oxides in the Ru/MgO catalyst was clearly shown to proceed at a lower temperature with the addition of Cs. Furthermore, the total reduction peak areas between 450 and 650 K were almost the same regardless of calcination temperature. These results indicated that Cs weakened the interaction between the Ru oxide species and MgO support, probably by promoting MgO crystallization, resulting in promotion of the reduction of Ru oxides. The electronic state of Ru formed on the catalyst where the reduction of Ru oxides was promoted by Cs was examined. Fig. 10 shows XP spectra obtained for the reduced Cs–Ru/MgO catalysts calcined at 773 or 923 K. In the Cs–Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at 773 K, the Ru 3d5/2 peak appeared at 280.0 eV, which was consistent with the binding energy of metallic Ru [45]. When the calcination temperature was raised to 923 K, the Ru 3d5/2 peak was observed at 280.0 eV, and the peak of Ru oxides such as RuO3 was not detected, indicating that the Ru oxide species were completely reduced to a metallic state by the addition of Cs. Promotion of the reduction of Ru oxides by Cs has been also reported by Larichev [43]. It has been reported that Cs species have an electronic promoter effect based on the finding that the Ru 3d5/2 peak shifts to a 1-eV lower binding energy in the presence of Cs [54,55]. However, our present findings clearly indicate that the addition of Cs does not affect the electronic state of Ru. We thus demonstrated that the role of Cs was to weaken the interaction between Ru and MgO rather than induces electronic modification of the Ru species. To confirm the chemical states of the reduced Ru, DRIFTS spectra of CO were obtained for Cs–Ru/MgO catalysts calcined at various temperatures (773–923 K) and then reduced at 773 K ( Fig. 11). A peak at around 2000 cm−1 and a shoulder peak from 1900 − 1950 cm−1 were observed, as was observed for Ru/MgO (Fig. 5); however, the shoulder peak was smaller in both intensity and width compared those in the Ru/MgO spectra. Peak deconvolution resulted in the CO adsorption peak being separated into two peaks, one at around 2000 cm−1 (linear-CO) and one at around 1940 cm−1 (bridge-CO), whose positions and intensity ratio were almost independent of the calcination temperature. The peak at around 1900 cm−1 observed for Ru/MgO (Fig. 5) was not detected for Cs–Ru/MgO, indicating that the strong CO adsorption sites present in Ru/MgO were removed by doping with Cs. That is, the Ru interacted strongly with MgO disappeared by the addition of Cs. We investigated why Cs-doped Ru/MgO showed a high activity for NH3 decomposition reaction. Because the rate-limiting step of this reaction is considered to be the associative desorption of adsorbed N atoms [30], the desorption temperature of N2 from the catalyst surface is strongly related to the NH3 decomposition activity. The TPD curves for N2 produced by the decomposition of NH3 over Ru/MgO or Cs–Ru/MgO are shown in Fig. 12. The temperature for the onset of N2 desorption for Ru/MgO calcined at 773 K was 450 K, and the desorption peak maximum appeared at 575 K. The desorption onset temperature was shifted to around 500 K for the Ru/MgO catalyst calcined at 923 K. Furthermore, the N2 desorption peak appeared at 590 K, indicating that the N2 desorption proceeded at a higher temperature as the calcination temperature increases. In contrast, the effect of calcination temperature on N2 desorption temperature was not confirmed for the Cs–Ru/MgO catalyst. The desorption onset temperature was 425 K, and the desorption peak maximum appeared at 550 K, with both values being lower than those for Ru/MgO. The desorption peak area for Cs–Ru/MgO was about twice as large as that for Ru/MgO, indicating that more NH3 decomposition occurred over Cs–Ru/MgO than over Ru/MgO. Thus, these findings clearly show that the associative formation of N atoms produced by the dissociation of NH3, which is the rate-limiting step of the NH3 decomposition reaction, was promoted by the addition of Cs. It is known that electron-deficient sites such as steps existed on Ru(0001) stabilize N atoms [56,57]. We therefore considered that the cationic Ru formed on our Ru/MgO catalyst stabilized the N atoms, resulting in decreased activity. Therefore, we concluded that the role of Cs was to maintain Ru in a metallic state, which is the active sites for NH3 decomposition, by weakening the interaction between Ru and MgO. 4 Conclusion We demonstrated that the catalytic activity of H2 production by NH3 decomposition over a Ru/MgO catalyst decreased with increasing calcination temperature. Here, we investigated the cause of this decrease and also how to improve the catalytic activity of Ru/MgO. Characterization analyses revealed that the interaction between the Ru oxides and MgO support became stronger with increasing calcination temperature. In addition, Ru reduced by H2 treatment was in a cationic state, which may have resulted in a decrease in the activity. To mitigate the decrease of activity induced by high-temperature calcination, we investigated the effect of doping with rare earth, alkali, or alkaline earth metals. All of the metals examined were found to improve the H2 production rate compared with that of the parent Ru/MgO catalyst. In particular, the addition of Cs enhanced the activity of the catalyst by 3.7 times compared with that of the parent Ru/MgO. We conducted further studies to clarify the role of Cs in mitigating the decrease of activity. Doping of the Ru/MgO catalyst with Cs weakened the interaction between the Ru oxide species and MgO support. As a result, the reduction of Ru oxides was promoted and Ru was maintained in a metallic state. This metallic Ru produced by the doping of Cs enhanced the associative formation of N2, which is the rate-limiting step of the NH3 decomposition. coredata.dc:description: The NH3 decomposition activity of Ru/MgO catalysts for the production of H2 decreases with increasing calcination temperature. Here, we found that this decrease in activity was the result of the interaction between the Ru and MgO support becoming stronger, causing formation of cationic Ru species. To mitigate this decrease in activity, we investigated the use of doping Ru/MgO catalysts with rare earth, alkali, or alkaline earth metals and found that Cs was particularly effective at enhancing catalytic activity, even at high calcination temperatures. Further examination revealed that doping with Cs weakened the interaction between the Ru and MgO support, resulting in the production of metallic Ru species. The metallic Ru produced by the doping of Cs enhanced the associative desorption of N atoms, which is the rate-limiting step of the NH3 decomposition reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Critical role of Cs doping in the structure and NH3 decomposition performance of Ru/MgO catalysts
